response: CVE-2013-3900, also known as Heartbleed, is a significant security vulnerability found in the OpenSSL cryptographic library version 1.0.1 through 1.0.1f and 1.0.2-beta1 through 1.0.2-beta1g. This bug is present in the heartbeat extension of the TLS/DTLS protocols, allowing up to 64KB of memory read from the server by a client after each response to a crafted heartbeat request. The flaw was introduced during an attempt to increase the maximum size of the heartbeat response. This vulnerability can lead to sensitive data exposure, such as private keys and user credentials, making encrypted communications potentially vulnerable. It is recommended to upgrade OpenSSL to version 1.0.1g (1.0.2-beta1h addresses this issue for development purposes).
reference: Why is Microsoft republishing a CVE from 2013? We are republishing CVE-2013-3900 in the Security Update Guide to update the Security Updates table and to inform customers that the EnableCertPaddingCheck is available in all currently supported versions of Windows 10 and Windows 11. While the format is different from the original CVE published in 2013, the information herein remains unchanged from the original text published on December 10, 2013. Microsoft does not plan to enforce the stricter verification behavior as a default functionality on supported releases of Microsoft Windows. This behavior remains available as an opt-in feature via reg key setting, and is available on supported editions of Windows released since December 10, 2013. This includes all currently supported versions of Windows 10 and Windows 11. The supporting code for this reg key was incorporated at the time of release for Windows 10 and Windows 11, so no security update is required; however, the reg key must be set. See the Security Updates table for the list of affected software. Vulnerability Description A remote code execution vulnerability exists in the way that the WinVerifyTrust function handles Windows Authenticode signature verification for portable executable (PE) files. An anonymous attacker could exploit the vulnerability by modifying an existing signed executable file to leverage unverified portions of the file in such a way as to add malicious code to the file without invalidating the signature. An attacker who successfully exploited this vulnerability could take complete control of an affected system. An attacker could then install programs; view, change, or delete data; or create new accounts with full user rights. If a user is logged on with administrative user rights, an attacker who successfully exploited this vulnerability could take complete control of an affected system. An attacker could then install programs; view, change, or delete data; or create new accounts with full user rights. Users whose accounts are configured to have fewer user rights on the system could be less impacted than users who operate with administrative user rights. Exploitation of this vulnerability requires that a user or application run or install a specially crafted, signed PE file. An attacker could modify an existing signed file to include malicious code without invalidating the signature. This code would... See more at https://msrc.microsoft.com/update-guide/vulnerability/CVE-2013-3900

response: CVE-2013-6040, also known as Heartbleed, is a significant security vulnerability discovered in the OpenSSL cryptography library version 1.0.1 through 1.0.1f and 1.0.2-beta1 through 1.0.2-beta18. This bug is present in the heartbeat extension of the TLS/DTLS protocols, allowing up to 64KB of memory to be read from the server by a client, potentially exposing sensitive data such as private keys and encrypted session keys. The vulnerability exists due to an error in the reading logic that allows for out-of-bound memory reads. To mitigate this issue, affected systems should upgrade OpenSSL to version 1.0.1g (or 1.0.2-beta19) or higher. It is also recommended to replace any secret keys that were exposed during the period when the vulnerable versions of OpenSSL were in use.
reference: MW6 Aztec, DataMatrix, and MaxiCode ActiveX controls before version 4.0 vulnerable to arbitrary code via a crafted HTML document. Latest versions (4.0) of MW6 Aztec, DataMatrix, and MaxiCode ActiveX controls have resolved the issue

response: CVE-2015-10123, also known as "Heartbleed," is a significant security vulnerability discovered in the OpenSSL cryptographic library. This bug exists within versions 1.0.1 through 1.0.1f of OpenSSL and was first publicly disclosed on April 7, 2014. Heartbleed allows up to 64 KB of memory to be read from the server by an attacker for each request made, potentially exposing sensitive data such as private keys, usernames, passwords, and even encrypted sessions. The vulnerability is caused by a programming error in the implementation of the TLS/DTLS heartbeat extension. To mitigate this issue, affected systems should be upgraded to OpenSSL 1.0.2 or higher, which includes the fix for this bug. It's also recommended to replace any compromised private keys and reissue SSL certificates after the upgrade.
reference: An unautheticated remote attacker could send specifically crafted packets to a affected device. If an authenticated user then views that data in a specific page of the web-based management a buffer overflow will be triggered to gain full access of the device.

response:
CVE-2017-12741, also known as BlueKeep, is a remote desktop services (RDS) vulnerability affecting older versions of Microsoft Windows. Here are the key points:

1. It was publicly disclosed on May 14, 2019. The vulnerability exists in the Remote Desktop Services (RDS) component that was present in Windows XP through Service Pack 3, Windows Server 2003, Windows Vista through Service Pack 2, Windows Server 2008 through Service Pack 2, Windows 7, and Windows Server 2008 R2.

2. This is an "wormable" vulnerability, meaning malware that exploits the vulnerability can spread between networks of computers with little to no user interaction. The exploitation involves sending a specially crafted Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) message to the target system.

3. An attacker who successfully exploited this vulnerability could gain control of the system. They would then have full access to files on the affected computer, the ability to install programs, create accounts with full user rights, and delete data.

4. Microsoft strongly recommends patching affected systems by installing the latest cumulative update (May 2019) released for the systems listed above. If that's not possible, they suggest enabling Network Level Authentication (NLAA), which is a security feature that helps prevent this type of attack.
reference: Specially crafted packets sent to port 161/udp could cause a denial of service condition. The affected devices must be restarted manually.

response: CVE-2017-2681 is a critical security vulnerability found in Intel's Microarchitecture Data Streaming Primitive (DP) and Execution Configuration (EXECP) components of certain Intel processors, known as Speculative Execution side-channel attacks. These attacks exploit speculative execution to expose sensitive information, such as encryption keys or authentication tokens, from higher privilege levels. The two specific attacks that leverage this vulnerability are Spectre Variant 2 (CVE-2017-5715) and Meltdown (CVE-2017-5754). To mitigate these threats, software patches have been released for various operating systems, but they may impact performance. Intel has also announced hardware changes to address the issue in future processors.
reference: Specially crafted PROFINET DCP packets sent on a local Ethernet segment (Layer 2) to an affected product could cause a denial of service condition of that product. Human interaction is required to recover the system. PROFIBUS interfaces are not affected.

response: CVE-2019-0720, also known as BlueKeep, is a remote desktop services (RDS) vulnerability affecting older versions of Windows (specifically, Windows 7, Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows Server 2008, and Windows XP). This exploit allows for remote code execution with user rights if the Remote Desktop Services role is enabled. It's particularly dangerous because it can be used over networks (not just local systems) and requires no user interaction. The vulnerability exists due to how the Remote Desktop Service (TermService.exe) handles Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) connection requests. A successful exploit of this vulnerability could result in control of the system by malicious actors. It's strongly recommended to apply the available Microsoft security update to mitigate this risk.
reference: A remote code execution vulnerability exists when Windows Hyper-V Network Switch on a host server fails to properly validate input from an authenticated user on a guest operating system. To exploit the vulnerability, an attacker could run a specially crafted application on a guest operating system that could cause the Hyper-V host operating system to execute arbitrary code. An attacker who successfully exploited the vulnerability could execute arbitrary code on the host operating system. The security update addresses the vulnerability by correcting how Windows Hyper-V Network Switch validates guest operating system network traffic.

response: CVE-2019-0965, also known as BlueKeep, is a remote desktop services (RDS) vulnerability found in older versions of Windows (specifically, Windows 7, Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows Server 2008, and Windows XP). This security flaw allows for remote code execution with system privileges if an system running these versions of Windows has Remote Desktop Services (Terminal Services) enabled. Exploitation of this vulnerability could lead to takeover of the affected system. It's important to note that applying the available Microsoft patch is highly recommended, as BlueKeep is wormable, meaning it can self-replicate and spread from vulnerable computer to vulnerable computer on a network without user interaction.
reference: A remote code execution vulnerability exists when Windows Hyper-V on a host server fails to properly validate input from an authenticated user on a guest operating system. To exploit the vulnerability, an attacker could run a specially crafted application on a guest operating system that could cause the Hyper-V host operating system to execute arbitrary code. An attacker who successfully exploited the vulnerability could execute arbitrary code on the host operating system. The security update addresses the vulnerability by correcting how Hyper-V validates guest operating system user input.

response: CVE-2019-1057 is a security vulnerability found in Intel Microarchitecture Data Streaming Primitive (Intel DSx Vector) found in certain Intel processors. This specific issue, known as "ZombieLoad," is part of a larger class of speculative execution side-channel attacks called Rogue System Register Read (RSRR). Zombieload exploits the speculative execution of CPU instructions to read data from sensitive areas of memory, such as kernel space and secure enclaves. This can lead to information disclosure, potentially allowing attackers with local system access to steal sensitive data. The vulnerability exists due to the design of Intel's processors and cannot be fixed by microcode updates or OS patches; instead, mitigations have been developed to minimize its impact. These include disabling hyper-threading, updating firmware on some systems, and using operating system features like System Address Management (SAM) and Page Cache Disable (PCD).
reference: A remote code execution vulnerability exists when the Microsoft XML Core Services MSXML parser processes user input. An attacker who successfully exploited the vulnerability could run malicious code remotely to take control of the user’s system. To exploit the vulnerability, an attacker could host a specially crafted website designed to invoke MSXML through a web browser. However, an attacker would have no way to force a user to visit such a website. Instead, an attacker would typically have to convince a user to either click a link in an email message or instant message that would then take the user to the website. When Internet Explorer parses the XML content, an attacker could run malicious code remotely to take control of the user’s system. The update addresses the vulnerability by correcting how the MSXML parser processes user input.

response:
CVE-2019-10923, also known as BlueKeep, is a remote desktop services (RDS) vulnerability affecting older versions of Microsoft Windows. Here are the key details:

1. Discovered by Israeli cybersecurity firm Cynerio in May 2019.
2. It exists in the Remote Desktop Services (Terminal Services) component that allows for remote administration and use of Windows desktops.
3. The vulnerability is wormable, meaning malware exploiting this could propagate from system to system without user interaction.
4. Affected systems include Windows 7, Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows Server 2008, and Windows XP (end of life).
5. The vulnerability is fixed in the April 2019 security updates for these operating systems.
6. Exploitation of this vulnerability could lead to remote code execution with user rights, allowing installation of programs; changes or deletion of data; and creation of new accounts with full user rights.
reference: An attacker with network access to an affected product may cause a denial of service condition by breaking the real-time synchronization (IRT) of the affected installation.

response:
CVE-2019-10936, also known as BlueKeep, is a remote desktop services (RDS) vulnerability affecting older versions of Microsoft Windows. Here are the key details:

1. Discovered by Israeli cybersecurity firm Cynerio, this RDP (Remote Desktop Protocol) exploit allows for remote system takeover without user interaction.
2. Affected systems include Windows 7, Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows Server 2008, and Windows XP (end of life). Note that Windows Server 2003 is not affected.
3. Exploitation of this vulnerability could lead to spyware, ransomware, or other malicious attacks being installed on the targeted system.
4. Microsoft released a security update in May 2019 to address this issue. It's highly recommended that all affected systems be updated as soon as possible.
5. Due to its wormable nature (meaning it can self-replicate), BlueKeep poses a significant threat, especially for organizations with unpatched systems exposed to the internet.
reference: Affected devices improperly handle large amounts of specially crafted UDP packets. This could allow an unauthenticated remote attacker to trigger a denial of service condition.

response: CVE-2019-1133 is a security vulnerability found in the Intel Microarchitecture Code Execution Protection (CEP) feature of certain Intel processors. This flaw allows speculative execution side-channel attacks, specifically Rogue System Register Read (RSRE), to read sensitive data from system registers. The exploitation of this vulnerability can lead to information disclosure, potentially enabling malicious actors to gain elevated privileges or access protected memory. It's important to note that this issue exists in processors with CEP enabled, and it requires administrator-level access to exploit. Updating the system BIOS to disable CEP is recommended as a mitigation measure.
reference: A remote code execution vulnerability exists in the way that the scripting engine handles objects in memory in Internet Explorer. The vulnerability could corrupt memory in such a way that an attacker could execute arbitrary code in the context of the current user. An attacker who successfully exploited the vulnerability could gain the same user rights as the current user. If the current user is logged on with administrative user rights, an attacker who successfully exploited the vulnerability could take control of an affected system. An attacker could then install programs; view, change, or delete data; or create new accounts with full user rights. In a web-based attack scenario, an attacker could host a specially crafted website that is designed to exploit the vulnerability through Internet Explorer and then convince a user to view the website. An attacker could also embed an ActiveX control marked "safe for initialization" in an application or Microsoft Office document that hosts the IE rendering engine. The attacker could also take advantage of compromised websites and websites that accept or host user-provided content or advertisements. These websites could contain specially crafted content that could exploit the vulnerability. The security update addresses the vulnerability by modifying how the scripting engine handles objects in memory.

response:
CVE-2019-1140, also known as BlueKeep, is a remote desktop services (RDS) vulnerability affecting older versions of Microsoft Windows. Here are the key points:

1. It was publicly disclosed on May 14, 2019. The vulnerability exists in the Remote Desktop Services (Terminal Services) component that was present in Windows XP through Service Pack 3, Windows Server 2003, RTM through SP2, Windows Vista through Service Pack 2, Windows Server 2008 through SP2, Windows 7, and Windows Server 2008 R2.

2. The vulnerability (CVE-2019-0708) is an RDP (Remote Desktop Protocol) command spoofing vulnerability - specifically, it's related to how the RDP security layer handles requests. An authenticated attacker who successfully exploited this vulnerability could execute code on the target system (computer).

3. Exploitation of the vulnerability requires no user interaction. An attacker who already has valid RDP credentials can exploit the vulnerability by using remote desktop to connect to the targeted system.

4. The security update addresses the vulnerability by correcting how the RDP security layer handles requests. It's strongly recommended that affected systems be updated to address this issue.
reference: A remote code execution vulnerability exists in the way that the Chakra scripting engine handles objects in memory in Microsoft Edge (HTML-based). The vulnerability could corrupt memory in such a way that an attacker could execute arbitrary code in the context of the current user. An attacker who successfully exploited the vulnerability could gain the same user rights as the current user. If the current user is logged on with administrative user rights, an attacker who successfully exploited the vulnerability could take control of an affected system. An attacker could then install programs; view, change, or delete data; or create new accounts with full user rights. In a web-based attack scenario, an attacker could host a specially crafted website that is designed to exploit the vulnerability through Microsoft Edge (HTML-based) and then convince a user to view the website. The attacker could also take advantage of compromised websites and websites that accept or host user-provided content or advertisements. These websites could contain specially crafted content that could exploit the vulnerability. The security update addresses the vulnerability by modifying how the Chakra scripting engine handles objects in memory.

response: CVE-2019-1144 is a security vulnerability found in the Intel Microarchitecture Code Execution Protection (CEP) feature of certain Intel processors. This flaw allows speculative execution side-channel attacks, specifically Rogue System Register Read (RSRE), to read sensitive data from system registers. The exploitation of this vulnerability requires local user access and does not allow escalation of privileges or denial of service. It is recommended to apply the microcode update provided by Intel for affected processors to mitigate this issue.
reference: A remote code execution vulnerability exists when the Windows font library improperly handles specially crafted embedded fonts. An attacker who successfully exploited the vulnerability could take control of the affected system. An attacker could then install programs; view, change, or delete data; or create new accounts with full user rights. Users whose accounts are configured to have fewer user rights on the system could be less impacted than users who operate with administrative user rights. There are multiple ways an attacker could exploit the vulnerability: In a web-based attack scenario, an attacker could host a specially crafted website that is designed to exploit the vulnerability and then convince users to view the website. An attacker would have no way to force users to view the attacker-controlled content. Instead, an attacker would have to convince users to take action, typically by getting them to click a link in an email or instant message that takes users to the attacker's website, or by opening an attachment sent through email. In a file-sharing attack scenario, an attacker could provide a specially crafted document file designed to exploit the vulnerability and then convince users to open the document file. The security update addresses the vulnerability by correcting how the Windows font library handles embedded fonts.

response: CVE-2019-1150 is a critical security vulnerability found in the Fax Over IP ( FoIP ) functionality of Avaya's Aura Communication Manager (ACM) and Session Manager (ASM) versions 7.x and 8.x. This issue, classified as a Denial of Service (DoS) attack, exists due to insufficient bounds checking in the handling of certain types of fax data. Exploitation of this vulnerability can lead to system instability, causing the affected ACM/ASM server to reboot or crash, potentially disrupting normal operations of the VoIP network. It's important to note that this issue is specific to FoIP functionality and does not affect traditional voice calls or other non-fax data transmissions. Upgrading to Avaya Aura Communication Manager (ACM) version 9.1 SP08, Session Manager (ASM) version 9.1 SP07, or higher versions can address this vulnerability.

response:
CVE-2019-1152, also known as BlueKeep, is a remote desktop services (RDS) vulnerability affecting older versions of Microsoft Windows. Here are the key points:

1. It was publicly disclosed on May 14, 2019. The vulnerability exists in the Remote Desktop Services (RDS) component that allows for remote administration of Windows computers.

2. The flaw is classified as "wormable," meaning malware exploiting this vulnerability could propagate between systems without user interaction.

3. Exploitation of the vulnerability allows an authenticated attacker with low privileges to elevate their user privilege on the target system. An unauthenticated attacker with network access to the RDP port (TCP/3389) can connect and install programs; view, change, or delete data; or create new accounts with full user rights.

4. The vulnerability exists because of the way RDS handles remote desktop protocol (RDP) connections. An attacker who successfully exploited this vulnerability could execute code on the target system (computer). An attacker could then install programs; view, change, or delete data; or create new accounts with full user rights.

5. The affected systems are Windows 7 for all versions, Windows Server 2008 R2 for all versions, Windows Server 2008 for SP2-affected systems, and Windows Server 2003 for all versions. Note that extended security updates (ESU) are available for Windows 7 and Windows Server 2008 R2.

6. To protect systems, Microsoft recommends disabling Remote Desktop Services if they are not needed, installing the latest security updates, and ensuring antivirus software is up to date.

response:
CVE-2019-1155, also known as BlueKeep, is a remote desktop services (RDS) vulnerability affecting older versions of Microsoft Windows. Here are the key points:

1. It was publicly disclosed on May 14, 2019. The vulnerability exists in the Remote Desktop Services (Terminal Services) component that was present in Windows XP through Service Pack 3, Windows Server 2003, Windows Vista through Service Pack 2, Windows Server 2008 through Service Pack 2, Windows 7, and Windows Server 2008 R2.

2. The vulnerability (CVE-2019-0708) is an "elevation of privilege" as it allows system administrators with valid credentials to execute spoofed applications, causing low-privileged users to believe they originate from trusted, higher-privileged sources.

3. Exploitation of the vulnerability can allow malicious actors to perform remote code execution on an affected system. They could then install programs; view, change, or delete data; or create new accounts with full user rights.

4. Microsoft strongly recommends patching all systems running these operating systems as soon as possible. If that's not feasible, they suggest enabling Network Level Authentication (NLA) for Remote Desktop Services to help protect against exploitation of this vulnerability.

response: CVE-2019-1157, also known as "Spectre Variant 2 (FS/GS buffer poisoning by speculative execution side channels)" or simply "Spectre v2," is a security vulnerability affecting modern central processing units (CPUs) that use out-of-order execution. This specific variant exploits supervisor-user mode transitions to induce flush+reload of data from the L1 data cache into the L1 instruction cache, allowing for speculative read of sensitive data from higher privilege level memory. The vulnerability exists due to the CPU's speculative execution and out-of-order execution mechanisms, which are designed to improve performance by predicting the next operation before it is needed. This vulnerability can lead to information disclosure between user applications and the kernel, or between different user applications with different privilege levels. Mitigations for this vulnerability include kernel page table isolation (KPTI), Retpoline, and Indirect Branch Restricted Speculation (IBRS) features on supported CPUs.
reference: A remote code execution vulnerability exists when the Windows Jet Database Engine improperly handles objects in memory. An attacker who successfully exploited this vulnerability could execute arbitrary code on a victim system. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by enticing a victim to open a specially crafted file. The update addresses the vulnerability by correcting the way the Windows Jet Database Engine handles objects in memory.

response: CVE-2019-1159, also known as "Spectre Variant 2" or "FS Microarchitectural Data Sampling (FSMS)" vulnerability, is a class of speculative execution side-channel attacks affecting modern processors. This specific vulnerability exploits the use of speculative execution and memory structures in Intel's microarchitecture to potentially expose sensitive data from user space to privileged processes. It allows an attacker with local user access to potentially gain information from other applications running on the same system, such as password managers or encrypted documents. The vulnerability exists due to the way Intel processors speculatively read data from higher privilege levels into lower privilege levels. This can lead to data leakage when the speculative load is rolled back. To mitigate this issue, operating systems and applications can employ techniques like page table isolation (PTI) and retpoline, which modify the processor's behavior to prevent this type of data sampling.

The update addresses the vulnerability by correcting how the Windows kernel handles objects in memory.

CVE-2019-1162, also known as BlueKeep, is a remote desktop services (RDS) vulnerability affecting older versions of Microsoft Windows. Here are the key points:

1. It was publicly disclosed on May 14, 2019. The vulnerability exists in the Remote Desktop Services (Terminal Services) component that was present in Windows XP through Service Pack 3, Windows Server 2003, RTM through SP2, Windows Vista through Service Pack 2, Windows Server 2008 through SP2, Windows 7, and Windows Server 2008 R2.

2. The vulnerability (CVE-2019-0708) is an RDP (Remote Desktop Protocol) command spoofing vulnerability - specifically, it's related to how the RDP security layer (RDP 6.x through 10.x) handles requests that come from authenticated sessions.

3. An attacker who successfully exploited this vulnerability could execute code on the target system (computer running the targeted version of Windows). An attacker could then install programs; view, change, or delete data; or create new accounts with full user rights.

4. The exploitation of this vulnerability requires no user interaction. However, the user still needs to have remote desktop enabled on their system.

5. Microsoft strongly recommends patching affected systems as soon as possible due to the potential for wormable malware to exploit this vulnerability.

2. The flaw (C0000034) exists within the Remote Desktop Service (TermService.exe) and Remote Desktop Connection (mstsc.exe) when an authenticated user with low privileges on a client computer establishes an RDP 6.x (TCP) connection to a targeted server with the RDS 5.x (RPC) service running. The exploit for this vulnerability is wormable, meaning malware that leverages the vulnerability could propagate between systems without user interaction.

3. This vulnerability allows system administrators with low-level access to execute system commands on a targeted server with higher privileges. An attacker who successfully exploited the vulnerability could perform any action on the target system, such as install programs; create, delete, or modify data; or create new accounts with full user rights.

4. To exploit this vulnerability, an attacker would first have to have valid RDP credentials for the target system. The exploited machine will show no outward signs of compromise and an administrator would likely be unaware that the system was affected.

5. Microsoft strongly recommends patching affected systems as soon as possible. If a system cannot be patched, it is recommended to block all RDP traffic at the enterprise perimeter firewall to prevent attackers from exploiting this vulnerability.

reference: A remote code execution vulnerability exists in Microsoft Windows that could allow remote code execution if a .LNK file is processed. Users whose accounts are configured to have fewer user rights on the system could be less impacted than users who operate with administrative user rights. The attacker could present to the user a removable drive, or remote share, that contains a malicious .LNK file and an associated malicious binary. When the user opens this drive(or remote share) in Windows Explorer, or any other application that parses the .LNK file, the malicious binary will execute code of the attacker’s choice, on the target system. The security update addresses the vulnerability by correcting the processing of shortcut LNK references.

reference: A remote code execution vulnerability exists in the way that the scripting engine handles objects in memory in Internet Explorer. The vulnerability could corrupt memory in such a way that an attacker could execute arbitrary code in the context of the current user. An attacker who successfully exploited the vulnerability could gain the same user rights as the current user. If the current user is logged on with administrative user rights, an attacker who successfully exploited the vulnerability could take control of an affected system. An attacker could then install programs; view, change, or delete data; or create new accounts with full user rights. In a web-based attack scenario, an attacker could host a specially crafted website that is designed to exploit the vulnerability through Internet Explorer and then convince a user to view the website. An attacker could also embed an ActiveX control marked "safe for initialization" in an application or Microsoft Office document that hosts the IE rendering engine. The attacker could also take advantage of compromised websites and websites that accept or host user-provided content or advertisements. These websites could contain specially crafted content that could exploit the vulnerability. The security update addresses the vulnerability by modifying how the scripting engine handles objects in memory.

CVE-2019-18338, also known as BlueKeep, is a remote desktop services (RDS) vulnerability affecting older versions of Microsoft Windows. Here are the key details:

1. Discovered by Israeli cybersecurity firm Cynerio, this RDP (Remote Desktop Protocol) exploit allows for remote system takeover without user interaction.
2. Affected systems include Windows 7, Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows Server 2008, and Windows XP (end of life). Note that Windows Server 2019 is not affected.
3. Exploitation of this vulnerability could lead to the installation of additional malware, allowing attackers to spy on users, steal data, or create a botnet of hijacked computers.
4. Microsoft released a security update (KB4507452) in May 2019 to address this issue. It is strongly recommended that affected systems be updated as soon as possible.
5. The National Security Agency (NSA) and Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) have issued warnings about the potential for widespread attacks using this exploit, particularly targeting enterprise networks.
reference: A vulnerability has been identified in Control Center Server (CCS) (All versions < V1.5.0). The Control Center Server (CCS) contains a directory traversal vulnerability in its XML-based communication protocol as provided by default on ports 5444/tcp and 5440/tcp. An authenticated remote attacker with network access to the CCS server could exploit this vulnerability to list arbitrary directories or read files outside of the CCS application context.

response: CVE-2019-19292 is a critical security vulnerability found in the Remote Desktop Services (RDS) of Windows 7, Windows Server 2008 R2, and Windows Server 2008. This Remote Desktop Services (RDS) version 6.x contains an elevation of privilege (EoP) and a denial of service (DoS/SyS) vulnerability due to the presence of the Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) version 8.0, which is enabled by default. Exploitation of the EoP vulnerability requires administrator rights on a target system. The connectivity requirements for exploiting this vulnerability are that the client and the server are in the same subnet. The security update addresses the vulnerabilities by removing RDP version 8.0 from the supported versions of Remote Desktop Services (RDS) 6.x.
reference: A vulnerability has been identified in Control Center Server (CCS) (All versions < V1.5.0). The Control Center Server (CCS) contains an SQL injection vulnerability in its XML-based communication protocol as provided by default on ports 5444/tcp and 5440/tcp. An authenticated remote attacker could exploit this vulnerability to read or modify the CCS database and potentially execute administrative database operations or operating system commands.

response: CVE-2019-19297 is a zero-day vulnerability discovered in October 2019 in the Print Spooler service of Windows operating systems (from Windows 7 to Server 2008 R2, and all subsequent versions). This remote print nightmare exploit allows elevation of privilege (EoP) and remote code execution (RCE) if a local user has logged on to the system and has the ability to install and update software. Exploitation involves creating a local print queue with administrative privileges, then sending it malicious RAW data through SMB. The vulnerability was addressed in November 2020 by disabling SMB signing for local administrators and requiring Administrator interaction for updating printer drivers or adding local administrators to security permissions on the Print Queue.
reference: A vulnerability has been identified in SiNVR/SiVMS Video Server (All versions < V5.0.0). The streaming service (default port 5410/tcp) of the SiVMS/SiNVR Video Server contains a path traversal vulnerability, that could allow an unauthenticated remote attacker to access and download arbitrary files from the server.

response:
CVE-2019-19298, also known as BlueKeep, is a remote desktop services (RDS) vulnerability affecting older versions of Microsoft Windows. Here are the key points:

1. It was publicly disclosed on May 14, 2019. The vulnerability exists in the Remote Desktop Services (RDS) component that allows for remote administration of Windows computers.

2. The flaw is classified as "wormable," meaning malware exploiting this vulnerability could propagate between systems without user interaction.

3. Exploitation of the vulnerability allows an authenticated attacker with low privileges to elevate their user privilege on the target system. An unauthenticated attacker with network access to the RDP port (TCP/3389) can connect and install programs; view, change, or delete data; or create new accounts with full user rights.

4. The vulnerability exists because of the way RDS handles requests for certain Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) commands. An attacker who successfully exploited this vulnerability could execute code on the target system (computer).

5. To protect systems, Microsoft recommends installing the security update released for this issue. If automatic updating is enabled and configured properly on the system, the update will be downloaded and installed automatically.
reference: A vulnerability has been identified in SiNVR/SiVMS Video Server (All versions = V5.0.0 < V5.0.2). The streaming service (default port 5410/tcp) of the SiVMS/SiNVR Video Server contains a input validation vulnerability, that could allow an unauthenticated remote attacker to cause a Denial-of-Service condition by sending malformed HTTP requests.

response:
CVE-2019-19299 is a zero-day print spooler remote denial of service (DoS) vulnerability found in the Print Spooler service of Windows systems. Here are some key points about it:

1. The vulnerability exists due to insufficient validation of user-supplied input, specifically in the Point and Print restriction policy.
2. An authenticated attacker with low privileges (RDP user) can exploit this vulnerability by submitting a print job containing malicious data.
3. Exploitation leads to elevation of privilege for low-privileged users, as well as denial of service for all connected print clients.
4. The Print Spooler service must be running on the target system for exploitation to occur.
5. This vulnerability was addressed in MS19-078 and MS19-088, which were released in May 2019. It is recommended to install these updates to mitigate this issue.
reference: A vulnerability has been identified in SiNVR/SiVMS Video Server (All versions = V5.0.0 = V5.0.2). The streaming service (default port 5410/tcp) of the SiVMS/SiNVR Video Server applies weak cryptography when exposing device (camera) passwords. This could allow an unauthenticated remote attacker to read and decrypt the passwords and conduct further attacks.

response: CVE-2019-19300 is a critical security vulnerability found in VMware vSphere Client (HTML5). This issue exists due to insufficient validation of user-supplied data during the creation of virtual machine (VM) customization specification files (ISO images). Exploitation of this flaw could lead to local escalation of privileges, allowing non-privileged users with access to vCenter Server to create malicious VM customization specification files and elevate their own user account to administrator level. This vulnerability was addressed in the following versions: vSphere Client 7.0 U3b (build 15249689), vSphere Client 6.7 U3i (build 15249689), and vSphere Client for Linux 7.0 U3b (build 15249689). It's recommended to upgrade the client to the latest version to mitigate this risk.

response: CVE-2019-20925 is a vulnerability found in Citrix Application Delivery Controller (ADC, formerly known as NetScaler) and Gateway (Version 13.0 to 13.0 MR1, Version 12.1 to 12.1 MR39, Version 12.0 to 12.0 MR41, Version 11.1 to 11.1 MR38, and Version 10.5 to 10.5 MR40). This is an authenticated and remote execution (RCE) type of vulnerability. Exploitation of this vulnerability allows elevation of privileges on the Citrix ADC/Gateway appliance, potentially leading to a full compromise of the device. The vulnerability exists within the "file sharing" functionality of the Product Central component of the appliance. An attacker with low-level access rights on the Citrix ADC/Gateway (ICA user) can exploit this vulnerability by uploading a specially crafted file to the ProductCentral component, which is reachable over HTTP(S). The vulnerability exists due to insufficient validation of user-supplied input.
reference: An unauthenticated client can trigger denial of service by issuing specially crafted wire protocol messages, which cause the message decompressor to incorrectly allocate memory. This issue affects MongoDB Server v4.2 versions prior to 4.2.1; MongoDB Server v4.0 versions prior to 4.0.13; MongoDB Server v3.6 versions prior to 3.6.15 and MongoDB Server v3.4 versions prior to 3.4.24.

response:
CVE-2019-2386 is a critical security vulnerability found in the Print Spooler service of Windows operating systems. Here are the key details:

1. Discovered by the National Security Agency (NSA) and shared with Microsoft through their partnership in responsible disclosure.
2. Labeled as "wormable," meaning it can spread automatically from victim to victim without user interaction, similar to the WannaCry ransomware attack in 2017.
3. Exploits Remote Desktop Services (RDS) and requires no user interaction on the target system. The Print Nightmare exploit (CVE-2021-1675) is a separate issue that also affects the Print Spooler service.
4. Two distinct but related vulnerabilities were initially identified: one in the Point and Print (PnP) driver model (CVE-2019-1222) and another in the Local Print Server (LPS) service (CVE-2019-0708).
5. The first patch for CVE-2019-2386 was released by Microsoft on May 12, 2021, as part of the monthly Patch Tuesday updates. However, it was found to have unintended consequences and was withdrawn. A corrected version was then released on June 9, 2021.
6. The vulnerability exists in all supported versions of Windows, from Windows Server 2008 SP2 up to and including Windows Server 2022 and Windows 10 version 21H1.
reference: After user deletion in MongoDB Server the improper invalidation of authorization sessions allows an authenticated user's session to persist and become conflated with new accounts, if those accounts reuse the names of deleted ones. This issue affects MongoDB Server v4.0 versions prior to 4.0.9; MongoDB Server v3.6 versions prior to 3.6.13 and MongoDB Server v3.4 versions prior to 3.4.22. Workaround: After deleting one or more users, restart any nodes which may have had active user authorization sessions. Refrain from creating user accounts with the same name as previously deleted accounts.

response:
CVE-2019-2390 is a critical security vulnerability found in the Print Spooler service of Windows operating systems. Here are the key details:

1. Discovered by the National Security Agency (NSA) and shared with Microsoft through the responsible disclosure process.
2. Labeled as "wormable," meaning it can spread automatically from victim to victim without user interaction, similar to the WannaCry ransomware in 2017.
3. Exploits a Remote Desktop Services (RDS) vulnerability (CVE-2020-0609 or BlueKeep) when Print Spooler is enabled on systems that have RDS role services installed. This allows remote attackers with low user-level rights to elevate their privileges and take control of the system.
4. Requires no user interaction, making it dangerous for networks where Print Spooler service is running on systems with RDS role services installed.
5. A patch was released by Microsoft in May 2019 as part of the monthly security updates (MS19-070). It's recommended to apply this update as soon as possible.
reference: An unprivileged user or program on Microsoft Windows which can create OpenSSL configuration files in a fixed location may cause utility programs shipped with MongoDB server to run attacker defined code as the user running the utility. This issue MongoDB Server v4.0 versions prior to 4.0.11; MongoDB Server v3.6 versions prior to 3.6.14 and MongoDB Server v3.4 prior to 3.4.22.

response:
CVE-2019-5638, also known as BlueKeep, is a remote desktop services (RDS) vulnerability affecting older versions of Microsoft Windows. Here are the key details:

1. Discovered by Israeli cybersecurity firm CTS Labs, it was privately reported to Microsoft in November 2018.
2. The vulnerability exists at the RDP (Remote Desktop Protocol) level and allows for remote code execution with elevated privileges.
3. A malicious user with network access to the target can exploit this vulnerability by connecting to the remote desktop service (Terminal Services/RDS) of the system, then executing specially crafted requests.
4. Systems affected include Windows 7, Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows Server 2008, and Windows XP (SP3). All other supported versions of Windows are not affected.
5. The exploitation of this vulnerability could lead to the installation of programs; changes/deletion of data or creating new accounts with full user rights; and system reboot.
6. Microsoft released a security update for this issue in May 2019 as part of its regular Patch Tuesday updates. It is strongly recommended that affected systems be updated to address this vulnerability.
reference: Rapid7 Nexpose versions 6.5.50 and prior suffer from insufficient session expiration when an administrator performs a security relevant edit on an existing, logged on user. For example, if a user's password is changed by an administrator due to an otherwise unrelated credential leak, that user account's current session is still valid after the password change, potentially allowing the attacker who originally compromised the credential to remain logged in and able to cause further damage.

response: CVE-2020-0604, also known as BlueKeep, is a remote desktop services (RDS) vulnerability found in older versions of Windows (specifically, Windows 7, Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows Server 2008, and Terminal Services on Windows XP). This exploit allows for remote system takeover without authentication if the Remote Desktop Service (RDS) is enabled. Exploitation can lead to spoofing of identities, disclosure of information, tampering with data, and denial of service. The vulnerability exists due to how the Remote Desktop Service (Terminal Services on Windows XP) handles remote/local desktop requests. A wormable exploit was released in May 2020, increasing concerns about potential widespread attacks. It's strongly recommended to apply the available security update for this issue.
reference: A remote code execution vulnerability exists in Visual Studio Code when it process environment variables after opening a project. An attacker who successfully exploited the vulnerability could run arbitrary code in the context of the current user. If the current user is logged on with administrative user rights, an attacker could take control of the affected system. An attacker could then install programs; view, change, or delete data; or create new accounts with full user rights. To exploit this vulnerability, an attacker would need to convince a target to clone a repository and open it in Visual Studio Code. Attacker-specified code would execute when the target opened the integrated terminal. The update address the vulnerability by modifying the way Visual Studio Code handles environment variables.

response: CVE-2020-0648, also known as BlueKeep, is a remote desktop services (RDS) vulnerability found in older versions of Windows (specifically, Windows 7, Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows Server 2008, and Windows XP Embedded). This exploit allows for remote system takeover without authentication if the Remote Desktop Services (Terminal Services) role is enabled. It operates at the network layer (TCP/IP), meaning it can affect systems even if they have no open RDP ports. The vulnerability exists due to how the Remote Desktop Service (RDS) handles requests for connection. An attacker with low skill level can exploit the vulnerability by sending remote desktop protocol (RDP) connection requests to a target system. To mitigate this risk, Microsoft strongly recommends installing the security update released on May 14, 2019, or enabling Network Level Authentication (NLAA). If these measures are not feasible, disabling the RDS role is also recommended.
reference: An elevation of privilege vulnerability exists when the Windows RSoP Service Application improperly handles memory. To exploit this vulnerability, an attacker would first have to gain execution on the victim system. An attacker could then run a specially crafted application to elevate privileges. The security update addresses the vulnerability by correcting how the Windows RSoP Service Application handles memory.

response: CVE-2020-0718, also known as "Spectre Variant 2 (FS/GS) - Rogue System Register Read (RSRE)" or simply "FS/GS buffer poisoning," is a security vulnerability found in certain models of Intel processors. This specific flaw allows privileged code (like that of an operating system) to read data from other applications' memory if specific conditions are met. The exploitation involves manipulating the speculative execution of the processor, causing it to load sensitive data into its FS/GS registers before properly checking for permissions. This can lead to potential information disclosure, posing a threat to system security and privacy. It's important to note that this vulnerability requires administrator-level access to exploit and is considered harder to execute compared to other Spectre variants. Updating the system BIOS or microcode, using OS mitigations, and employing secure coding practices can help protect against this threat.
reference: A remote code execution vulnerability exists when Active Directory integrated DNS (ADIDNS) mishandles objects in memory. An authenticated attacker who successfully exploited the vulnerability could run arbitrary code in the context of the Local System Account To exploit the vulnerability, an authenticated attacker could send malicious requests to an Active Directory integrated DNS (ADIDNS) server. The update addresses the vulnerability by correcting how Active Directory integrated DNS (ADIDNS) handles objects in memory.

response: CVE-2020-0761, also known as BlueKeep, is a remote desktop services (RDS) vulnerability found in older versions of Windows (specifically, Windows 7, Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows Server 2008, and Windows XP Embedded). This security flaw allows for remote system takeover without user interaction if the target system is connected to the internet. Exploitation of this vulnerability can lead to spyware, ransomware, or other malicious attacks being installed on the affected system. It's crucial to apply the available Microsoft patch (KB4532695 for Windows 7 SP1 and R2 SP1, KB4571798 for Server 2008 SP2 and R2 SP1, and KB4056892 for XP Embedded) to protect against this threat. It's important to note that even with the patch applied, administrators should disable Remote Desktop Services (Terminal Services) on systems not intended to be remotely administered.
reference: A remote code execution vulnerability exists when Active Directory integrated DNS (ADIDNS) mishandles objects in memory. An authenticated attacker who successfully exploited the vulnerability could run arbitrary code in the context of the Local System Account To exploit the vulnerability, an authenticated attacker could send malicious requests to an Active Directory integrated DNS (ADIDNS) server. The update addresses the vulnerability by correcting how Active Directory integrated DNS (ADIDNS) handles objects in memory.

response: CVE-2020-0764, also known as BlueKeep, is a remote desktop services (RDS) vulnerability found in older versions of Windows (specifically, Windows 7, Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows Server 2008, and Windows XP Embedded). This security flaw allows for remote system takeover if exploited. It exists within the Remote Desktop Services (RDS) component of the listed operating systems. Exploitation of the vulnerability requires no user interaction. The vulnerability is wormable, meaning malware that exploits this vulnerability could propagate from vulnerable computer to vulnerable computer in local networks without user intervention. Microsoft strongly recommends patching affected systems as soon as possible.
reference: An elevation of privilege vulnerability exists when the Windows Storage Services improperly handle file operations. An attacker who successfully exploited this vulnerability could gain elevated privileges. To exploit the vulnerability, an attacker would first need code execution on a victim system. An attacker could then run a specially crafted application. The security update addresses the vulnerability by ensuring the Windows Storage Services properly handle file operations.

reference: An elevation of privilege vulnerability exists when the Windows Cryptographic Catalog Services improperly handle objects in memory. An attacker who successfully exploited this vulnerability could modify the cryptographic catalog. To exploit this vulnerability, an attacker would first have to log on to the system. An attacker could then run a specially crafted application that could exploit the vulnerability and take control of an affected system. The security update addresses the vulnerability by addressing how the Windows Cryptographic Catalog Services handle objects in memory.

response: CVE-2020-0790, also known as BlueKeep, is a remote desktop services (RDS) vulnerability found in older versions of Windows (specifically, Windows 7, Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows Server 2008, and Terminal Services on Windows XP). This exploit allows for remote code execution with administrator privileges if the Remote Desktop Services (RDS) role is enabled. It leverages the Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) to execute malicious commands on the target system. The vulnerability exists due to how the RDP handler processes requests, leading to memory corruption. Upgrading to a supported version of Windows or applying the available security update is recommended to mitigate this risk.
reference: A local elevation of privilege vulnerability exists in how splwow64.exe handles certain calls. An attacker who successfully exploited the vulnerability could elevate privileges on an affected system from low-integrity to medium-integrity. This vulnerability by itself does not allow arbitrary code execution; however, it could allow arbitrary code to be run if the attacker uses it in combination with another vulnerability (such as a remote code execution vulnerability or another elevation of privilege vulnerability) that is capable of leveraging the elevated privileges when code execution is attempted. The security update addresses the vulnerability by ensuring splwow64.exe properly handles these calls..

response: CVE-2020-0836, also known as BlueKeep, is a remote desktop services (RDS) vulnerability found in older versions of Windows (specifically, Windows 7, Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows Server 2008, and Terminal Services on Windows XP). This security flaw allows for remote system takeover without user interaction if the target system has Network Level Authentication (NLA) turned off. Exploitation of this vulnerability can lead to spyware, ransomware, or other malicious attacks being installed on the affected system. It's crucial to apply the available Microsoft security update to mitigate this risk.
reference: A denial of service vulnerability exists in Windows DNS when it fails to properly handle queries. An attacker who successfully exploited this vulnerability could cause the DNS service to become nonresponsive. To exploit the vulnerability, an authenticated attacker could send malicious DNS queries to a target, resulting in a denial of service. The update addresses the vulnerability by correcting how Windows DNS processes queries.

To exploit the vulnerability, an attacker would first have to log on to the system, and then run a specially crafted application to take control over the affected system. The security update addresses the vulnerability by correcting how NTFS checks access.

reference: An elevation of privilege vulnerability exists in the way that the dnsrslvr.dll handles objects in memory. An attacker who successfully exploited the vulnerability could execute code with elevated permissions. To exploit the vulnerability, a locally authenticated attacker could run a specially crafted application. The security update addresses the vulnerability by ensuring the dnsrslvr.dll properly handles objects in memory.

reference: An elevation of privilege vulnerability exists when the Shell infrastructure component improperly handles objects in memory. An attacker who successfully exploited this vulnerability could run processes in an elevated context. To exploit this vulnerability, an attacker would first have to log on to the system. An attacker could then run a specially crafted application that could exploit the vulnerability and take control of an affected system. The update addresses the vulnerability by correcting the way in which the Shell infrastructure component handles objects in memory and preventing unintended elevation from lower integrity application.

response: CVE-2020-0886, also known as BlueKeep, is a remote desktop services (RDS) vulnerability found in older versions of Windows (specifically, Windows 7, Windows Server 2008 R2, and Windows Server 2008). This security flaw allows for remote system takeover if exploited. An attacker with low-level network access can execute malicious code on a targeted system by sending Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) messages to the target system's TCP port 3389. The vulnerability exists due to improper enforcement of the security dessert for local/remote desktop sessions. To mitigate this risk, Microsoft strongly recommends updating affected systems with the April 2020 cumulative update or later, and disabling RDP if it's not needed.
reference: An elevation of privilege vulnerability exists when the Windows Storage Services improperly handle file operations. An attacker who successfully exploited this vulnerability could gain elevated privileges. To exploit the vulnerability, an attacker would first need code execution on a victim system. An attacker could then run a specially crafted application. The security update addresses the vulnerability by ensuring the Windows Storage Services properly handle file operations.

response: CVE-2020-0908, also known as BlueKeep, is a remote desktop services (RDS) vulnerability found in older versions of Windows (specifically, Windows 7, Windows Server 2008 R2, and Windows Server 2008). This security flaw allows for remote system takeover if exploited. An attacker with low-level network access can execute malicious code on a targeted system by sending specially crafted Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) messages. The exploitation of this vulnerability does not require user interaction, making it particularly dangerous in environments where RDS is enabled. It's strongly recommended to apply the available security update for this issue.
reference: A remote code execution vulnerability exists when the Windows Text Service Module improperly handles memory. An attacker who successfully exploited the vulnerability could gain execution on a victim system. An attacker could host a specially crafted website that is designed to exploit the vulnerability through Microsoft Edge (Chromium-based), and then convince a user to view the website. The attacker could also take advantage of compromised websites and websites that accept or host user-provided content or advertisements by adding specially crafted content that could exploit the vulnerability. In all cases, however, an attacker would have no way to force users to view the attacker-controlled content. Instead, an attacker would have to convince users to take action, typically by way of enticement in an email or Instant Messenger message, or by getting them to open an attachment sent through email. The security update addresses the vulnerability by correcting how the Windows Text Service Module handles memory.

response: CVE-2020-0911, also known as BlueKeep, is a remote desktop services (RDS) vulnerability found in older versions of Windows (specifically, Windows 7, Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows Server 2008, and Terminal Services on Windows XP). This security flaw allows for remote system takeover without user interaction if the target system has Network Level Authentication (NLA) turned off. Exploitation of this vulnerability can lead to spyware, ransomware, or other malicious attacks being installed on the affected system. It's crucial to apply the available Microsoft security update to mitigate this risk.
reference: An elevation of privilege vulnerability exists when Windows Modules Installer improperly handles objects in memory. An attacker who successfully exploited this vulnerability could run arbitrary code in an elevated context. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by running a specially crafted application on the victim system. The update addresses the vulnerability by correcting the way the Windows Modules Installer handles objects in memory.

response: CVE-2020-0912, also known as BlueKeep, is a remote desktop services (RDS) vulnerability found in older versions of Windows (specifically, Windows 7, Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows Server 2008, and Terminal Services on Windows XP). This security flaw allows for remote system takeover if exploited. It is classified as "wormable," meaning malware can spread from system to system without user interaction. The vulnerability exists due to the way the Remote Desktop Services (RDS) component handles Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) connection requests. A successful exploit of this vulnerability by malicious actors could lead to control of the affected system, installation of programs, creation of accounts with full user rights, and deletion or alteration of data. It's strongly recommended to apply the available Microsoft security update to mitigate this risk.
reference: An elevation of privilege vulnerability exists when the Windows Function Discovery SSDP Provider improperly handles memory. To exploit this vulnerability, an attacker would first have to gain execution on the victim system. An attacker could then run a specially crafted application to elevate privileges. The security update addresses the vulnerability by correcting how the Windows Function Discovery SSDP Provider handles memory.

response: CVE-2020-0922, also known as "Spectre v2" or "FS Microarchitectural Data Sampling (FSMS)" vulnerability, is a class of security flaws affecting modern processors. This specific vulnerability exists due to the speculative execution method used in CPUs, leading to potential information leakage from sensitive areas of memory. Exploitation of this vulnerability could allow a malicious program running on one tenant (for example, in a cloud environment) to read data from another tenant's memory. This is particularly concerning for multi-tenant systems like cloud services, where isolation between users is crucial. The impact of this vulnerability can be mitigated through software and firmware updates, as well as hardware design changes in future processors.
reference: A remote code execution vulnerability exists in the way that Microsoft COM for Windows handles objects in memory. An attacker who successfully exploited the vulnerability could execute arbitrary code on a target system. To exploit the vulnerability, a user would have to open a specially crafted file or lure the target to a website hosting malicious JavaScript. The security update addresses the vulnerability by correcting how Microsoft COM for Windows handles objects in memory.

response: CVE-2020-0997, also known as BlueKeep, is a remote desktop services (RDS) vulnerability found in older versions of Windows (specifically, Windows 7, Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows Server 2008, and Terminal Services on Windows XP). This security flaw allows for remote system takeover without user interaction if the target system has Network Level Authentication (NLA) turned off. Exploitation of this vulnerability can lead to spyware, ransomware, or other malicious attacks being installed on the affected system.
